[b]Intro[/b]

Sniper Elite 4 is a stealth/action third person shooter in which you explore medium-large sized locations and kill fascists.

[b]The Good[/b]

- You get to kill tons of fascists, including Hitler himself! (it's the real Hitler this time)
- As usual, the killcam shows in beautiful gory detail how your bullets kills fascists.
- Levels are way bigger than they were in SE3 and you have much more freedom.
- There's a little skill system which allows you to pick between two skills for six slots.
- There's silent ammo for rifles and pistols, making sniping much less reliant on environmental sounds and allowing you to pick non-Welrod pistols.
- Grenades and mines have two different modes now (usually a delay).
- TNT can self-explode now.
- More variety in enemies.
- You can shoot almost all lamps now.
- Nice locations.
- You can create a detailed custom difficulty.
- Challenges, ribbons, etc. are nice additions.
- Weapon unlock system encourages playing differently.

[b]The Bad[/b]

- Weapon unlock system includes some really annoying and grindy challenges.
- Pointless unlock system for some weapons and consumables.
- Some weapons seem useless.

[b]The Ugly[/b]

Both a mission of the DLC campaign and the "kill Hitler" mission have super-annoying alarms that cannot be turned off.

[b]Conclusion[/b]

This is a vast improvement over SE3, just like it was a huge leap from SE2. It basically feels like the shackles have come off and the player is finally truly free to take out the enemy like they want to. Recommended to anyone who loves sneaky murder man games.

First playthrough review time.

Sniper Elite 4 keeps the same base as the earlier game but brings a few useful changes. Now, movement is more flexible with the ability to crouch-run, climb, and take cover in bushes. These help during stealth, which works better than before. There are also more options to stay quiet during missions. The shooting system is mostly the same, but the kill cam has better visuals and now appears during melee attacks and trap kills too. Even with that, enemy bodies often look untouched after being hit, which reduces some of the impact.

The maps in this game are larger and offer more space to move around. Missions can still be completed quickly if you go directly to the main targets, but there is more to do if you decide to explore. Some weapon upgrades are unlocked by reaching certain numbers in kills or shots, which gives small goals to aim for. The game has several difficulty levels and the highest one gives very little help to the player and makes early attempts hard unless the map is already known. While the online multiplayer part is nearly empty on some systems, the co-op mode is still usable.

Overall, this game is a better version of the one before it. It does not bring big changes but improves many small things. The story remains simple and the campaign is short, but the bigger maps and better stealth systems give the player more ways to move through missions. It stands as the strongest title in the series so far and gives a solid experience for those who prefer slow and methodical approach to gameplay.

It feels like this game wasn't designed to be a Sniper Elite game, or at least not what I'd expect from the series.

Levels seldom have interesting sight lines, lack cool sound-masking opportunities, have otherwise useful tools in useless locations, force you into hallways and narrow spaces indoors, and are just generally not fun to engage with. The terrible design then heavily encourages the use of suppressed ammo for your sniper (or a silenced pistol) that comes off as lazy level design, made worse when the sound-masking generators you do find are tucked away in worthless locations.

Sniping doesn't feel great either since enemies are extremely twitchy/jank and do not move as you would expect. This compounds with the over-tuned bullet drop and wind, with soldiers shrugging off any shots that don't immediately hit their head or heart (some even shrug off 2 point-blank shotgun shots to the chest while unarmored). Headshots are almost always best, but the challenges to upgrade your snipers force you to do non-sniper gameplay such as under 20m kills. I also don't really remember many good opportunities for fun 300+ meter shots.

The game just continuously asks you to engage with uninteresting and underbaked mechanics that really don't feel thought out or evolved at all, which isn't even mentioning the forgettable story, cutscenes, and characters that all came from a terrible movie, or the DLC guns that are just better than the base game stuff. If any new ideas do come up, they remain unexplained and randomly show up (mostly in the DLC) as one time "cool" ideas that don't really do anything. None of this changed between stealth and loud tactics either, with the bad enemy AI showing its age regularly.

I honestly don't understand why so many seem to think this is the best in the series, as it delivers on almost none of my expectations from past games. While some credit should be given with how old the game is, I am frankly just very disappointed in the experience overall.
